Anna Toledano

Anna Toledano is a PhD candidate at Stanford University in history of science. Her dissertation, ?Collecting Empire: The Science and Politics of Natural History Museums in New Spain, 1770?1820,? focuses on natural history collecting in eighteenth-century Spain and Spanish America. She is also a museum professional and developed content for exhibitions and collections at the New York Botanical Garden from 2012 to 2015.

Cindy Ermus

@cindyermus
Follow

Cindy Ermus

Cindy Ermus (@CindyErmus) is Assistant Professor of History at the University of Lethbridge. She has published on disease and disaster management in eighteenth-century Europe and the Atlantic, and she is the editor of a volume entitled, Environmental Disaster in the Gulf South: Two Centuries of Catastrophe, Risk, and Resilience (LSU Press, 2018). Her current book project is a transnational study of the Plague of Provence of 1720 (?Great Plague of Marseille?), one of the last outbreaks of plague in Western Europe. She is also co-founder, executive editor, and contributor at AgeofRevolutions.com.

Audra J. Wolfe

@ColdWarScience
Follow

Audra J. Wolfe

Audra J. Wolfe, Ph.D. is a Philadelphia-based writer, editor, and historian. She is the author of Freedom?s Laboratory: The Cold War Struggle for the Soul of Science (2018) and Competing with the Soviets: Science, Technology, and the State in Cold War America (2013). Her articles have appeared in both scholarly and more popular venues, including the Washington Post, The Atlantic.com, Slate, and the popular podcast American History Tellers. Wolfe holds a Ph.D. in the History and Sociology of Science from the University of Pennsylvania (2002). Previously, she studied biochemistry and chemistry at Purdue University (B.S., 1997). She has taught courses on Cold War science as well as science and the media at the University of Pennsylvania. As a publishing professional, Wolfe has worked at the University of Pennsylvania Press, Rutgers University Press, and the Chemical Heritage Foundation, where she additionally served as executive producer for an award-winning podcast, Distillations. Her editorial and publishing consulting company, The Outside Reader, supports the work of scholars and scholarly publishers. Additional information is available on Wolfe?s website, http://audrajwolfe.com. She tweets @ColdWarScience.

Conevery Bolton

@Conevery
Follow

Conevery Bolton

Historian of science, medicine, environment, and energy who writes and teaches at Boston College. Currently finishing a book about mid-American earthquakes, induced seismicity, and the shale boom, with science journalist Anna Kuchment (@akuchment). Co-winner along with Peter Kastor of 2012 Margaret W. Rossiter Prize for the History of Women in Science from HSS for our article on the health of Sacagawea in the Lewis &amp; Clark Expedition. Past books: The Lost History of the New Madrid Earthquakes (2013): history of Mississippi Valley quakes in 1811-12 that impacted US settlement, Indian emigration and Native resistance, bodily well-being, religion, and war, but were forgotten and elided until recent seismology has made them again an object of scientific study and disaster preparation. The Health of the Country: How Americans Understood Themselves and Their Land (2002): exploration of the profound connections understood to exist between bodily health and environmental well-being in the 19th century, connections which shaped US settlement, racial ideas, agriculture, and medical science. Winner of the 2003 George Perkins Marsh book prize from the American Society for Environmental History. Other writings: medical geography, the medical work of Anton Chekhov, health travel, the 20th-century language system ISOTYPE, women?s health in the 19th century. Awards &amp; support from National Endowment for the Humanities, Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study, Dibner Institute for the History of Science &amp; Technology, Arkansas Women?s History Institute. Always glad to talk earthquakes, energy, health/environment relations, 19th-c fiction, or regionally-correct pronunciation of ?Missouri.?

Dana Simmons

@danajsimmons
Follow

Dana Simmons

My research interests include hunger, nutrition, soil, political economy, the human sciences and feminist theory. I am author of _Vital Minimum: Needs, Science and Politics in Modern France_. I am currently working on a history of the science and politics of hunger and food insecurity in the postwar period. I have a side project on the history of the Impostor Syndrome. I am also faculty co-organizer of the UCR Science Studies group, which is committed to building a community inclusive of marginalized knowledge makers in STS.

Michael Barton

@darwinsbulldog
Follow

Michael Barton

Michael D. Barton is an independent historian of science, interested in Darwin and the history of evolutionary thought, often shared through his blog The Dispersal of Darwin. He currently is co-editor for two volumes of the Correspondence of John Tyndall (University of Pittsburgh Press), and previously worked on the Tyndall Correspondence Project as a letter transcriber. In 2018, he began work as a freelance transcriber for the Alfred Russel Wallace Correspondence Project. He received both his MA (2010) and BA (2008) in History from Montana State University (Bozeman, MT). His MA paper, ?The ?efficient defender of a fellow-scientific man?: John Tyndall, Darwin, and Preaching Pure Science in Nineteenth-Century America,? looked at the physicist Tyndall?s support for Darwin.

David Robertson

@davidjr9711
Follow

David Robertson

I am a doctoral candidate in Princeton University?s Program in the History of Science. My historical interests include colonial and postcolonial history, the history of anthropology, and the history of the human sciences with an emphasis on the mind sciences. Previously I obtained an MA in history from the University of Sydney. My thesis examined the history of psychiatric fieldwork undertaken in Aboriginal communities across the second half of the twentieth century. My dissertation investigates efforts to standardize psychiatric classification and practice from the 1950s onward with an emphasis on the role that medical instruments played in this process. Toward this end I am currently living in Geneva, where I am engaged in ongoing research in the organization?s archives.

Christine Keiner

@DrSerpentine
Follow

Christine Keiner

I am a historian of science, politics, and the marine environment, and I teach a variety of courses dealing with the history of science, technology, and the environment in the Science, Technology, and Society Department and the History Department at RIT. My book The Oyster Question: Scientists, Watermen, and the Maryland Chesapeake Bay since 1880 (University of Georgia Press, 2009) won the 2010 Forum for the History of Science in America Prize (History of Science Society), Maryland Preservation Award for Outstanding Heritage Book (Maryland Historical Trust), and Honorable Mention for the Frederick Jackson Turner Award (Organization of American Historians). My forthcoming book addresses the environmental history of the unbuilt Central American sea-level canal.

She also teaches HPS at Lyman Briggs College, MSU. A proud Canadian, Ellie studied at Bishop's, the IHPST (MA) and York's STS program (PhD), where her research focused on wildlife documentaries, spectacle, and staging practices. She tweets about higher ed, HPS, museums, science-art collaborations, and work-life balance.

Karl Galle

Follow

Karl Galle

Historian of astronomy and other mathematical arts, especially but not exclusively in the context of Germany, Poland, and other parts of Central Europe during the late Medieval and Renaissance eras. I currently live in Cairo, Egypt, and had a post-PhD career in science policy and international development, which means my Twitter feed will also occasionally reflect scholarly news or interests in those areas. My largest ongoing project is a biographical study of Nicholas Copernicus and his contemporaries that attempts to give greater weight to his political, administrative, and diplomatic activities.

Ry Marcattilio-Mccracken

Ry Marcattilio-Mccracken

I am an historian specializing in the history of science and medicine in the United States. I work as a Lecturer at Oklahoma State University (teaching online courses) and as an Adjunct Professor (teaching live courses) at Southwest Minnesota State University. Currently, I?m writing a book about eugenics, sterilization, and carceral power at a girls? reform school in Kansas (to be complete in 2018?see page for more details). I have taught the American history survey as well as courses on the Gilded Age, Modern Civ 1500-present, American Thought and Culture, and WWII. I have in the past also taught courses on the history of evolutionary theory, magical realism in literature, and composition and rhetoric.

Geoff Bil

@geoffbil
Follow

Geoff Bil

My research centers on interactions between scientific and vernacular knowledge systems, with particular reference to plants and the environment. My doctoral thesis, &quot;Indexing the Indigenous: Plants, Peoples and Empire in the Long Nineteenth Century,&quot; examined the shifting significance of indigenous knowledge in relation to scientific botany. I'm currently pursuing a follow-up project, entitled &quot;Fields of Empire: Science, Ethnoscience and the Making of the American Century,&quot; which extends these concerns by looking at American engagements with Southeast Asian and Latin American indigenous knowledges under the emerging disciplinary rubrics of ethnobotany and ethnoecology. In general, I'm fascinated by knowledge circulations and translations between disciplines, cultures and localities. My work also strives to imbricate imperial histories of science with present-day colonial contexts, and incorporate indigenous critical perspectives alongside STS approaches.

Michael D. Gordin

@GordinMichael
Follow

Michael D. Gordin

I teach the history of modern and contemporary science at Princeton University, with a specialization in the physical sciences and Russian, European, and American history. Author of: A Well-Ordered Thing: Dmitrii Mendeleev and the Shadow of the Periodic Table (revised edition 2019); Scientific Babel: How Science Was Done Before and After Global English (2015); The Pseudoscience Wars: Immanuel Velikovsky and the Birth of the Modern Fringe (2012); Red Cloud at Dawn: Truman, Stalin, and the End of the Atomic Monopoly (2009); and Five Days in August: How World War II Became a Nuclear War (2007). He does not own a tie with the periodic table on it.

Greg Priest

@greg_m_priest
Follow

Greg Priest

Greg Priest is a PhD candidate (ABD) in History and a member of the Program of History and Philosophy of Science at Stanford University. Greg focuses on the history of evolutionary biology, particularly Charles Darwin. He also works on philosophy of history, narrative, and scientific diagramming. Greg's most recent publication is a 2018 article on Darwin?s tree diagrams in a special issue of the journal Endeavour devoted to the practice of scientific diagramming, a special issue that Greg conceived and of which he was principal editor. His article ?Charles Darwin?s Theory of Moral Sentiments: What Darwin's Ethics Really Owes to Adam Smith? won the 2017 Forkosch Prize for the best article published in the Journal of the History of Ideas.

The Hopos Journal

@hoposjournal
Follow

The Hopos Journal

HOPOS is the official journal of the International Society for the History of Philosophy of Science. The Editor of the journal posts updates on articles and reviews in the journal and news from the profession.

Isis Journal

@IsisJournal
Follow

Isis Journal

Isis is a publication of the History of Science Society. Since its inception in 1912, Isis has featured scholarly articles, research notes and commentary on the history of science, medicine, and technology, and their cultural influences. Review essays and book reviews on new publications in the field are also included. This is the oldest (and most widely circulating) English-language journal in the field.

Jim Fleming

@JFleminghistory
Follow

Jim Fleming

Jim Fleming is the Charles A. Dana Professor of Science, Technology, and Society at Colby College, Maine. He has written extensively on the history of weather, climate, technology, and the environment including social, cultural, and intellectual aspects. His books include Meteorology in America (Johns Hopkins, 1990), Historical Perspectives on Climate Change (Oxford, 1998), The Callendar Effect (AMS, 2007), Fixing the Sky (Columbia, 2010), Inventing Atmospheric Science (MIT, 2016), and Into the Clouds: Joanne Simpson and the Tropical Atmosphere (MIT, in press). Profile: http://www.colby.edu/profile/jfleming

Katalin Straner

@KatiStraner
Follow

Katalin Straner

I am a historian of modern Europe, specialising in the history of science, urban history and the study of translation and reception in the history of ideas. Most of my work has focused on the history of Habsburg Central Europe, more specifically Hungary, in the long nineteenth century. My research interests include the academic and popular reception of Darwinism and evolution in Hungary and Central Europe; the study of knowledge production and transfer in the long nineteenth century; the role of the city and urban culture, including the urban press, in the circulation and transformations of knowledge; the history of scientific societies, associations and institutions; and the effect of migration and exile on knowledge transfer.

Kevin Baker

@kevinbaker
Follow

Kevin Baker

I am a historian of science, technology, and international politics. My work examines the place of computers and expertise in global affairs. Specifically, I research the ways that computer modeling has informed global environmental, economic, and development policy and how these simulations have shaped our collective dreams and nightmares of the future. My current project is a history of The Limits to Growth report. Released in 1972 by the Club of Rome, Limits was a landmark environmental text that used a computer simulation model called ?World3? to argue that humanity was heading on a course towards environmental and economic collapse by the middle of the 21st century. My dissertation, ?World Processors: Computer Simulation, the Limits to Growth, and the Birth of Sustainable Development,? provides an intellectual biography of the World3 model, charting its unlikely origins and showing how its designers sought to convince a skeptical global public of the truth of its conclusions.

Massimo Mazzotti

@maxmazzotti
Follow

Massimo Mazzotti

Professor, Department of History, and Director, Center for Science, Technology, Medicine and Society, UC Berkeley. My research interests lie at the intersection of the history of science and science studies. I focus on the historicity and situatedness of mathematics, logic, and deductive reasoning, and on the social processes that can make them universally valid. I am also interested in using technological systems and artifacts as entryways to understanding forms of social organization and power distribution. From the eighteenth century to the present. Current projects: mathematics and political reaction; Olivetti design; algorithmic life.

Sjang Ten Hagen

Sjang Ten Hagen

I am a historian of science and humanities based at the University of Amsterdam. For my current PhD project, I study relations between the disciplines of physics and history in nineteenth-century Germany. I have worked on the reception of the theory of relativity as well, and I am genuinely interested in all kinds of historical examples of interdisciplinarity.

Sarah Qidwai

@skidwayy
Follow

Sarah Qidwai

Sarah Qidwai is a PhD Candidate at the Institute for the History and Philosophy of Science and Technology at the University of Toronto. Her research broadly focuses on the history of science and Islam in Colonial India. Her thesis situates Sayyid Ahmad Khan (1817-1898) as a key figure in the history of science in colonial India. Through an interdisciplinary approach, including the history of science and religion and South Asian Studies, she investigates the development and implementation of Sayyid Ahmad?s scientific thought (including human evolution and the motion of the earth) and how he dealt with science?s role in its historical context.
